Ishan Dhwani

Interface design for Soundscapes

For my first Semester Thesis Project, I created Ishān Ishan Dhwani, which aims to represent the various dialects, demographics, and recordings of the Assamese language in a medium.

The speech data were collected from native speakers of Assamese from various geographical locations in Assam.

For: Design Project 1 (DD216)

Duration: Jan 2020 to May 2020

Mentor: Dr Abhishek Shrivastava

Status: Completed

Link: Click here to visit

Source Code: GitHub

OVERVIEW

The main objective of the project was to redesign a soundscape interface, with the Assamese language as a use-case, while creating a compelling visual interface.

A research project under the HSS Dept of IIT-G studied the effects of socio-linguistic factors on vowel pattern variation across different dialects of Assamese spoken in the Brahmaputra valley.

I was tasked to create a well-designed interface which showcases this data collected from the research for anyone in the world to access and interpret it.

INSIGHTS

Data is inherently difficult for the human brain to understand and retain. Most adults can only store between 5 and 9 items in their short-term memory.

By turning complex numbers and other pieces of information into visuals, data becomes easier to follow and use.

Soundscapes are a sonic landscape. It is the total acoustic values related to a particular place.

Information can easily be interpreted when we create an abstraction with the sounds from the soundscape. While the user listens to the sounds, he can read and understand the data served to him via the soundscape interface.

DESIGN PROCESS

EXISTING DESIGNS

There were majorly 2 soundscape designs. We analysed them and found out the flaws in them.

The Soundsslike Project used small dots as identifiers for sounds. On click, it plays the audio along with details about the place.

  • The identifiers are too tiny to click.
  • The icons are placed too close together, and misclicks are common.
  • There is a lot of wasted space around the interface which took most of the screen.

The Soundscape World had a different approach. It consists of a player with multiple buttons and a lot more control of the audio. These were categorised into the nature of the sound. This design was completely different from Soundsslike.

  • There is no information regarding the sounds.
  • It doesn't correctly guide the user to its functions.

CONCEPT

After days of repeated reading of the project report, we finally concluded that the following data should be represented on the page.

Audio Recordings
Dialect Map
Level of Pride Data
Graduated Distribution Terms

We followed a tabbed design to differentiate the functions easily. We used different colours for different screens to indicate the data it’s providing. The following are the concept sketches.

Listen Tab

The user can listen to speech recordings from various districts of Assam. These, when clicked, show a pop-up with multiple play buttons placed accurately.

Dialects Tab

Shows the different dialects across the state. One can hover over a region to see what variety they speak, their popularity and how proud they are of their language.

Words Tab

Shows the distribution of lexical terms. Twelve terms were selected, which had multiple synonyms to study the usage of these words in different regions. We put these terms in a grid, and we showed the distribution using a gradient. The darker the shade, the more frequent the word was used in that region.

DESIGN LANGUAGE

Logo
Font
Colour Pallete
UI Elements

FINAL DESIGNS

We developed the platform using HTML5, with Bootstrap 4 as the front-end framework for CSS. JavaScript, accompanied by the jQuery library, was used to handle the back-end of the website. We are currently hosting it on GitHub pages.

Previous Next

FUTURE SCOPE

We completed our first phase of the project, and we have even bigger plans for the future, including -

  • Subtitles for the speech recordings.
  • Allowing users to contribute to the project by uploading their recordings.
  • A function to record your voice and identify which area your voice matches the most.
